#Text=PierCarlo Di Lietto
#Text=Warning :
#Text=Page using Template : Infobox officeholder with unknown parameter " religion " ( this message is shown only in preview ) .
#Text=Pierre-Charles de Liette ( born PierCarlo Di Lietto ) was an Italian who moved to French North America and enrolled there as French soldier .
#Text=He served as aide to Henri de Tonti , as commandant at Fort Saint-Louis and Chécagou , and as a captain in the colonial regular troops from 1687 to 1729 .
#Text=He was also Commander of the Illinois Country .
#Text=Biography
#Text=Pierre De Liette was born probably in Gaeta ( southern Italy ) with the name Piero Carlo Di Lietto , around 1672 .
#Text=He moved to New France around 1685 and lived in Quebec for some time .
#Text=There he changed his name in a more adapted French version :
#Text=De Liette or Desliette .
#Text=Di Lietto served 15 years under Henri de Tonti ( who was his cousin ) , which began with his arrival at Fort Saint-Louis at Le Rocher ( Starved Rock ) in 1687 .
#Text=Initially the young De Liette lived with the Illinois and Miami tribes hunting , trading and learning their language and customs .
#Text=After three years , satisfied with the progress of his cousin , Tonti entrusted him with the command of Fort Saint-Louis .
#Text=Later he appointed him to supervise the resettlement of the Illinois .
#Text=During the French and Indian Wars , the French used the Fort Saint Louis as a refuge against attacks by Iroquois , who were allied with the British .
#Text=But in 1692 , the fort was evacuated after being attacked by the Iroqouis .
#Text=The Illinois village and the garrison were moved to a new location at Fort Pimitoui ( now Peoria ) .
#Text=De Liette then served as interim commandant at Fort Chécagou , where Tonti maintained a warehouse ( and also at Fort Pimetoui until 1702 ) .

#Text=Indeed the Fort Chécagou ( or Fort Chicago ) was built in 1685 by Henri de Tonti and later Pierre-Charles de Liette was the main commander of the fort through 1702 , probably creating the first civil settlements in the area of what is now Chicago .
#Text=During one of his visits to Montreal de Liette wrote the " De Gannes Memoir , " preserved in the Ayer Collection , Newberry , Library , Chicago .
#Text=Although someone named De Gannes signed the memoir , internal evidence alone proves de Liette 's authorship .
#Text=Almost 50 printed pages in length , this document is a valuable account of the Illinois and Miami Indians , and of the country in which they lived .
#Text=— C.J.Russ
#Text=Fort de Chartres , commanded by De Liette in 1725
#Text=From 1702 until 1711 De Liette remained the only representative of the French government among the Indians in the area , mainly because of his knowledge of their language .
#Text=He was in charge of mediation between the Miami and Illinois tribes and was successful even with countering the English trade ventures in the area .
#Text=De Liette fought bravely the Fox tribe and in 1725 was named Commandant of the " Illinois country " while in charge of the Fort de Chartres .
#Text=Pierre-Charles de Liette died in May 1729 , [ 1 ] after having spent most of his adult life in the West .
#Text=He explored the Mississippi valley in detail , while in close contact with the Illinois tribe ( of which he described the social patterns in some documents [ 2 ] ) .
#Text=Piercarlo Di Lietto and Enrico Tonti are ranked as two major explorers of North America .
